page.title: 04ECOLOGY, THEBERTON
page.content: Bird life abounds, small birds at home in woods and near houses, hovering kestrels and large barn owls at dusk. Sea gulls follow the tractor and lapwings flock in winter. In the lanes spring brings a bounty of primroses, cowslips, then alexanders, cowparsley soon made bright by poppies, daisies, comfrey, yarrow, ragwort and willow herb in the drainage trenches. Glimpses of deer can be caught in the dark woods but there in spring, besides the pens for hand reared pheasants, is a carpet of purple orchids. White posts enclose parts of verge where a rarer plant is growing telling the hedge cutter that it is a protected species and must not be cut. Sometimes stoats streak across the roads but in late springsome roads are covered in young frogs seeking new ponds. There are hares and rabbits.
